Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story: I stared at my phone, reading the message from my boyfriend for the third time. “We need to talk tonight. This can’t go on.” My stomach twisted. We’d argued about money all week, and I knew he expected me to help resolve things, to be calm and understanding, to listen and find a way forward. But my shift at the hotel had just started, and I was already behind. The supervisor had warned us again about wearing gloves for every cleaning task—no exceptions. I usually slipped them on only for the worst jobs, but today, with inspections looming, I couldn’t risk it. My hands were raw, my mind distracted, replaying our arguments and his disappointed face. Every time I reached for the gloves, I thought about him waiting for me to fix things, to be the supportive girlfriend he needed. But here, I was supposed to be the perfect cleaner, following every rule, no matter how tired or preoccupied I felt. The demands pressed in from both sides, and I felt myself pulled apart, unsure which role I could afford to let down.
